text: was a Japanese era name (年号, nengō, lit. year name) of the Northern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Kōan and before Ōan. This period started in September 1362 and ended in February 1368.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "'Jōji','" Japan Encyclopedia, p. 430. The pretender in Kyoto was .Nussbaum, "Go-Kōgon Tennō," p. 255; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 302-308. Go-Kōgon's Southern Court rival in Yoshino during this time was .Nussbaum, "Go-Murakami Tennō," p. 257. ==Events of the Jōji era == * 1365 (Jōji 4): Prince Kaneyoshi gained control of Kyūshū.Ackroyd, Joyce. (1982) Lessons from History: The Tokushi Yoron, p.329. * 1367 (Jōji 6): Ashikaga Motouji died; and Yoshiakira gave his position to his son.Titsingh, p. 307. * 1368 (Jōji 7): Ashikaga Yoshimitsu became the third shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate.Titsingh, p. 308. ==Southern Court nengō== * Shōhei, 1346–1370 ==Related pages== * Muromachi period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Jōji 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 1362 1363 1364 1365 1366 1367 1368 Preceded by: Kōan Northern Court nengō: Jōji Succeeded by: Ōan Category:Japanese eras Category:1360s establishments in Japan Category:1360s disestablishments in Japan
title: Jōji
